text:
Avocado image
Perspective from Faith Seke PhD, Agronomy and Crop Science (ongoing), Master’s degree, Food Science and Technology · 1 years of experience · South Africa Benefits
Avocados are a good source of vitamin K which is necessary for blood clotting and preventing excessive bleeding. Avocados are a good source of potassium and the amount is higher than other fruits, with a 100 gram serving containing 14% of the recommended daily allowance. Avocados are high in fiber, which can contribute to weight loss, reducing blood sugar spikes and also assisting in lowering the risk of diseases. A 100 gram serving of avocados will contain about 7 grams of fiber and 27% of the recommended daily allowance. Quantity Recommendation
I would recommend the consumption of half avocado or less a day, half avocado contains about 120 calories and eating avocado everyday can help to improve bad cholesterol levels in overweight and obese people. → Avocado: How much should you eat? Experts weigh in.

Perspective from Carolina Castro PhD Candidate (Health Services), Post Graduate Functional Clinical Nutrition, Bachelor’s Degree Nutrition and Dietetics · 7 years of experience · Australia Benefits
Avocado is one of the most important fruits for brain health, is full of nutrients as healthy fats, magnesium, manganese, copper, iron, zinc, vitamin A and B complex. Avocado is full of monounsaturated oleic fats important ingredient for heart health, control of lipid levels and has anti inflammatory effects. Avocado is rich of soluble fibers, important to feed good gut bacteria and also may have benefits in weight control. Avocado is packed in antioxidants as carotenoids and zeaxanthin essential nutrients for vision health and may prevent cancer. Quantity Recommendation
I recommend half of the fruit daily to increase fiber and good fat content, also get all benefits from the antioxidants and anti-inflammatory compounds. Can take with seeds as chia or in preparations as guacamole. → Avocado: How much should you eat? Experts weigh in.
